channel.title: SMF vs phpBB
channel.description:
A majority of my members have been telling me that SMF is far better than phpBB. This is going to be a thread dedicated to pure education as to which is truly better.
Take everything critical, nothing personal. I will be defending phpBB, as it's my default software right now. So, elaborate; which do you think is better, and why?
I'd say phpBB is better because it has more of a professional approach. Sure, it's complicated, but that's what makes it so great. It's complex and can offer many more features than SMF. Everything about it is naturally elegant. The only thing I'd have to say bad about it is the fact that users aren't used to it. It's a little complicated at first, but it's nothing different from basic use of SMF.
Simple Machines gets it's name from it's position in forum software; simple. I agree, it's really easy to use and everyone is used to it, but it's [i]too[/i] simple. A lot of the themes are cheep or cheesy, the basic layout doesn't flow very well, and all together it's the lower quality of the forum software family. I'm not completely downing SMF. Like I said early, there has to be some reason why everyone loves SMF. It's the user friendliness.
So, how about yourself? Care to defend your forum?
Edit: Almost forgot, for the users that haven't used phpBB, here's the site forum: [url=http://www.phpbb.com/community/?sid=6c644da3be1cbd3ba888ffde73388e51]phpBB Community[/url]

item.title: SMF vs phpBB
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“ollie123, post:56, topic:312044”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=408485.msg3019855#msg3019855 date=1257522453]

@MITB:

You said there was no “major security flaw” with-in SMF since you began using it… However, what about JDB creating multiple global accounts? He wasn’t an administrator when he did that, was he?

That seem’s like a major security flaw to me

That as actually Mopar’s choice. He gave global mods access to the registration page, which isn’t a “standard” permission for global moderators. I don’t think the smf developers intended for non-maintenance and non-administrators to be able to create new accounts at all.

If anything, I’d blame the vague permissions of smf. I’d be happier myself if there were 3 times more permissions which gave you exactly what you wanted.
[/quote]

You’d like phpBB, the permissions are as granular as hell.[/quote]

Perhaps. I’m usually torn between an extremely controlled permission framework (complex) with a feature-lacking forum (simple).

Read full topic

item.title: SMF vs phpBB
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

phpBB, in my experience, is not nearly as good as SMF, for multiple reasons.

  1. phpBB has always had more bugs (or ‘exploits’) than SMF and they have always been of a more serious nature. In the years since I have been using SMF (since 2006) there has never once been any serious bugs in the software that allowed anyone to gain any staff permissions or anything that affected the forum at all. phpBB has had these kind of exploits.

  2. Last time I checked (granted it has been awhile, it likely has changed since then) phpBB uses md5 as the hashing algorithm for the passwords (fairly easy to crack, using rainbow tables), and sends the passwords in clear text from the browser to the server. SMF uses sha1 hashes, and actually hashes your password with javascript in your browser and only sends the hash over the network, meaning that even if someone is sniffing your network, or even if the server administrator steals your hash, there is no way they can ever get your actual password.

  3. Simply by the structure of phpBB, it is more easily exploitable and prone to bugs than SMF. With SMF, everything is handled through index.php. This means that the same code is used each time to check permissions, input, login status, login and everything else. Also index.php is the single and only entry point into the software, if you want to do something extra, for example make people agree to a TOS, you just edit this one page. However, phpBB (along with vBulletin, same flaw) uses multiple entry points into the application (just a few I could find, search.php, community.php, index.php, post.php, view.php, etc, etc) This means duplicate code that doesn’t have to be there, and more of a likelihood of a bug in this code, AND if there is a bug with anything, it has to be fixed in every single one of those files, making more of a chance it won’t get fixed correctly or even allowing a new bug to be introduced. And good luck if you are going to add a TOS or some other check to your forum, because you have to edit every single one of these files.

I’m sure there are other reasons as well, those are just a few that made me go with SMF (before it was cool to go with SMF ;)) Other things such as look and layout are just preference, I HATE the way phpBB looks, and LOVE SMF, but that doesn’t make one better than the other.

edit:

[quote=“Newty, post:26, topic:312044”]open source

edit: (smf that is)[/quote]

Actually that is a plus phpBB has going for it. phpBB is far more open source than SMF is, using an actual open source license, the GNU GPL. SMF isn’t really open source, because although the code is available for you to look at, you are not allowed to modify and re-distribute it. It is one thing that makes me hate SMF.

Read full topic
